author: 责编：张燕萍
title: 独居老人在家离世，生前囤积成癖，留下满屋的垃圾尴尬了……
text:
4NWtAxNgi2n society.huanqiu.com article 独居老人在家离世，生前囤积成癖，留下满屋的垃圾尴尬了…… /e3pmh19vt/e3ps21dgq “囤积癖” 带来的困扰
让不少人饱受其害
↓↓↓
刺鼻的味道
肮脏的居住环境
……
这样的情况
小坊也曾多次报道过
想要把垃圾清理
还居民一个干净的环境
也是阻力重重
最近
虹口区玉田新村的多位居民
也遇到了这样的窘境
更 麻烦 的是
↓↓↓
囤积这些垃圾的老人
在今年5月下旬突然离世
至今两个多月过去了
一直没有人来清理满屋的垃圾
居民通过新闻坊同心服务平台反映称
小区里有位独居老伯
生前留下了满屋子的垃圾
最近天气越来越热
房间里也是臭气熏天
老鼠、蟑螂都来了
除了卫生问题
更让居民们担心的是
老人家里阳台的玻璃
也破损已久
常年敞开着摇摇欲坠
卫生问题 + 安全隐患
让居民们很是 担忧
蔡先生 附近楼栋居民：
老鼠窝、黄鼠狼窝，再加上台风天风一大，窗户玻璃都被震坏了，玻璃都被砸下来好几块了。
昨天（15日）中午
坊记在涉事楼层的走廊中
闻到一股 浓重的臭味
为此左邻右舍都是 门窗紧闭
老人隔壁邻居： 一直都有味道，我对象说听到过隔壁老鼠的声音。
对楼老年居民： 老鼠窜来窜去左右跑，我天天在这里洗菜，看到老鼠会跑进他家的房间里去。
据居民们介绍，该户业主是位年近七旬的独居老人， 因囤积杂物而产生的卫生问题已长达10年之久 ，大家曾多次与老人沟通，希望能够帮助清理，但却收效甚微。
附近楼栋老年居民： 我以前一直劝他的，说这个房子居委帮你大扫除，搬搬弄弄不是很好吗？他虽然口头上答应，但就是没有行动。
由于家中被垃圾占满无法居住
老人索性就在附近小区
另租了一间房
今年5月下旬
老人被发现
过世在租住的房屋中
李阿姨 老人租住房屋的邻居：
他喜欢捡东西的，垃圾桶堆满，走廊外面也堆得一塌糊涂。5月份的时候，我们在走廊里闻到臭味，后来有一个认识他的朋友来敲门也找不到人，居民报警后才发现老人已在家中过世一周。
除了唏嘘外
谁来处理老人堆在家中的杂物
也成为了一道现实的难题
附近楼栋老年居民：
事发当天，老人的嫂子等家属三人都来了，既然他过世了你们应该来收拾呀，他们家里姐妹也不来的，就这样放在这里，也没有人来处理。这事情应该谁来做？居委会是不是现在应该来处理了？
坊记从属地居委了解到，过世的这位老伯姓王，是一位69岁的独居老人，没有结婚也没有子女，此前是小区里的热心人。
10年前，王老伯的双亲离世，他继承了房产，而囤积行为也从那时起初见端倪，由于邻居频繁投诉，居委也曾与老人沟通，但都遭到了对方的婉拒。
顾衷新 玉三居委会工作人员：
自从他父母去世后就开始在家堆垃圾了，此前居民来多次反映说有味道还堆物，我们居委会开过几次"三所联动"，也做了思想工作，哥哥嫂嫂也乐意给出钱给他清扫、装修，但是他本人不愿意， 他爸妈留下的东西、捡来的垃圾不许人家动 。
王老伯还有大哥、大嫂、妹妹及一位侄女，事发后居委第一时间联系了老人的大哥，当时家属表示，由于弟弟离世突然， 如何处置房产及海量垃圾如何清理，家庭成员仍需做进一步商讨。
由于担心老伯家中
有贵重物品
属地也无法在未经授权的情况下
进行房屋清理
卢戈润 玉三居民区党总支书记：
需要哥哥嫂嫂来处理老人的后事，遗产继承什么占用了比较多的时间，再加上天气比较热，还有身体的原因，所以就耽搁了。房子长期关着的，在没有家属首肯的情况下，或者没有相关法条情况下，我们肯定不可能自说自话去破门的，所以现在还在不断在和家属沟通，希望能够早点达成共识。
经过沟通，今天（16日）上午，王老伯的亲属在小区与坊记见了面，打开老伯的家门， 一居室的房屋被杂物和垃圾塞得无处下脚，刺鼻的酸臭味让大家望而却步。
王老伯的外甥女斯女士告诉记者，舅舅、舅妈已年过7旬， 家属也试图清理过几次，但忙活了一整天却连冰山一角都清不了。
此外
由于房产证可能也被埋在房间内
几位亲属对房屋处置
仍没有头绪
事情就搁置至今
斯女士 王老伯外甥女：
困难点肯定也是有的，我们家属也做了努力，但东西实在太多了，全部都堆满了，说得夸张点，要几卡车来拉。门都开不开，厨房里很小一部分东西已经清理掉了，基本有可以站立的地方。消杀和清理是达成一致的，我们也在积极努力在做这个工作，由于力量有限，推进得很慢很慢。
法律界人士表示，在产证无法找到的情况下，房产继承手续实际也有方法可循， 因此建议清理消杀与遗产继承同步进行，清理期间可让第三方在场全程录像为证，先解决卫生问题与安全隐患。
经过现场商议与律师普法
几方达成了初步共识
↓↓↓
王老伯家属 表示将尽快和属地一起开展清扫工作，争取在本周内完成清理；
属地 也将在家属应允的前提下提供帮助，并介绍专业机构对房屋进行消杀；
物业 也将对破损门窗进行修缮，消除安全隐患。
小坊希望堆满垃圾的房子
能早日清理干净
周边的邻居
早日拥有一个干净的居住环境
逝去的老人也能安息
记者｜李仕婧、朱勇

author: 闫景臻

author: Tribune News Service
title: Vaccines for low income children lag behind, CDC study finds – Boston Herald
text:
Helena Oliviero | The Atlanta Journal-Constitution (TNS)
A new report released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows gaps remain in Vaccines for Children, a federally funded program to provide free vaccines to low-income families, with lower vaccination coverage among children living in poverty remaining a persistent problem.
This study comes on the heels of another study by the CDC which found that over the past 30 years, routine childhood vaccinations have prevented approximately 508 million cases of illness, 32 million hospitalizations and 1.1 million deaths. But despite these substantial health benefits, attitudes toward childhood vaccinations have shifted, and they are increasingly tough sell.
A Gallup poll published recently found that just 40% of Americans think it’s “extremely important” for children to get vaccinated, down from about 64% in 2001.
Reaching families at or below the poverty line can be even more difficult. CDC officials pointed to a lack of confidence and a lack of access to vaccines as key reasons for the lower rates among VFC eligible children. They noted vaccine uptake in the first year of life is generally higher and then falls especially among vaccinations requiring multiple doses over several years.
“We need to do more,” said CDC Chief Medical Officer Dr. Debra Houry at a press briefing Tuesday. “Health care providers are our crucial partners to increase the number of children who complete their vaccine series and reach those children living below the poverty level without health insurance.”
The study does not include state specific information but major findings of vaccination coverage from 2012 to 2022 in the U.S. include:
— Only 61% of children born in 2020 who were VFC-eligible received the seven vaccines known as the “combined 7-vaccine series” by their second birthday. This series includes all recommended doses of diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (whooping cough) (DTaP) vaccine, polio vaccine, measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, the Hib vaccine protecting against Haemophilus influenzae type b bacteria , the hepatitis B vaccine, chicken pox vaccine, and the a vaccine (PCV) that helps protect against bacteria that cause pneumococcal disease. Among children not VFC eligible also born in 2020, the vaccination rate for this combined 7-vaccine series was 75%.
— About 90% of VFC-eligible children born in 2020 received at least one dose of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine (MMR) vaccine. Among those not VFC eligible, coverage rate with at least one dose of MMR vaccine is about 93%.
— Vaccination coverage was also lower among uninsured children than among Medicaid-insured children. Uninsured children are more likely to have not seen a health care provider in the past year. They are less likely to complete vaccine series that require multiple doses. The vaccination rate was about 62% for the combined 7 vaccines for those with Medicaid coverage and about 39% for those without insurance.
Houry pointed to important steps by health care providers to help reassure families vaccines about the importance of getting the vaccine, including the following: Offering accurate information on vaccination benefits; giving catch-up vaccines and review for needed vaccines; strengthening relationships with families and setting reminders for families whose children are behind on vaccines.
The Vaccines for Children program supplies vaccines for free to participating providers. Children across the country can be eligible in this program aimed at helping those who would not otherwise be able to afford vaccinations. In Georgia, the vaccines are available to children up to 19 years of age who are:
— Medicaid Enrolled
— Uninsured (child has no health insurance coverage) or underinsured
— is American Indian or Alaska Native
The Vaccines for Children program is administered nationally by CDC. The federal government purchases pediatric vaccines at a discount and ships them directly to enrolled VFC vaccine providers in Georgia and across the country. Administrative fees for administering vaccines in this program are generally covered by Medicaid.
Related Articles Health |

author: TW
title: Severe drought across northern Indiana after 3rd driest October in 127 years
text:
Almost all (99.87%) of Indiana is experiencing some level of drought (D0-D4), with 68.14% in moderate drought (D1) or higher, and 34.65% in severe drought (D2) or higher — almost all of it in northern Indiana. Comparatively, a year ago, only 63.16% was under drought conditions, with a much smaller portion experiencing severe drought.
Three months ago, on July 30, a much larger area (82.08%) was drought-free. Now, only 0.13% remains free from drought.
A Red Flag Warning was issued for northern Indiana on Tuesday, October 29, 2024, as gusty winds up to 56 – 64 km/h (35 – 40 mph), the temperature near 26 °C (80 °F), and dry conditions made fires in agricultural land become a common event this week.
October 2024 is now officially recorded as the third driest October in 127 years for Fort Wayne. With only 11 mm (0.43 inches) of rain, it marks the driest October since 1964.
Only 42.4 mm (1.67 inches) of rain fell in October at the South Bend International Airport, making it the driest month in 9 years and more than 50 mm (2 inches) below the monthly average total.
VERY DRY OCTOBER IN SOUTH BEND: 1.67" of rain fell this month across just 5 days. This was the driest October in 9 years and was more than 2 inches below the typical monthly total. pic.twitter.com/ivmmbKpj4Q
— NWS Northern Indiana (@NWSIWX) November 1, 2024 INCREDIBLY DRY OCTOBER: October 2024 officially goes into the record books as the 3rd driest October in 127 years for Fort Wayne, IN! With only 0.43” of rain this month, this October was the driest since 1964. pic.twitter.com/ALqHPmB968
— NWS Northern Indiana (@NWSIWX) November 1, 2024 The monthly Climate Prediction Center outlook for November favors above normal temperatures (40-50% chances) and above normal precipitation (33-50% chances). With ongoing drought this fall, a return to a more active weather pattern is certainly welcome! pic.twitter.com/Oy3Kb4Cvgm
— NWS Northern Indiana (@NWSIWX) November 1, 2024 The monthly Climate Prediction Center outlook for November predicts above-average temperatures of about 40 to 50% chance and precipitation of about 33 to 50% chance.
Northern Indiana is home to significant agricultural areas, especially for corn and soybeans, which are the state’s primary crops. The region also supports wheat, hay, and livestock farming, which are essential to both the local and national agricultural economy.
Counties like Allen, Dekalb, and Elkhart are particularly known for their large-scale farming operations. Additionally, northern Indiana has a mix of smaller specialty farms producing tomatoes, mint, and melons.
Agriculture here is highly sensitive to drought conditions, as dry weather can reduce crop yields, stress livestock, and affect overall productivity.
The recent increase in drought conditions, as well as record-low rainfall in areas like Fort Wayne, could have substantial impacts on crop health, soil moisture, and farming sustainability in the region.
1 Weather forecast for Northern Indiana – NWS – November 1, 2024
2 Indiana Drought Monitor – DroughtMonitor – October 29, 2024

author: Società Editrice Athesis S.p.A.
title: I lavoratori al caldo: «Giusto fermarsi. Ma a luglio è tardi per dare regole e provvedimenti» | Bresciaoggi
text:
Sono le 9 di mattina ma il termometro segna già 30 gradi. Sotto il sole, gli operai dei numerosi cantieri della città lavorano a pieno ritmo già dalle prime ore di luce. Per alcuni di loro il turno è iniziato alle 5, per altri alle 6: la certezza è che nel rispetto dell’ordinanza regionale in vigore da ieri, 2 luglio, per tutti coloro che svolgono attività all’aperto nel settore edile, agricolo e florovivaistico è previsto uno stop dalle 12.30 alle 16.
«A mezzogiorno noi ci fermiamo – dichiara Antonio Migliorati, responsabile dell’importante cantiere edile di via Sostegno -. Sicurezza e salute prima di tutto, anche se alcune lavorazioni devono essere per forza rinviate dopo la fine di questa ondata di calore, facendo slittare alcune operazioni».
«L’ordinanza è giusta e puntuale – sostiene Ivan, che lavora sul metanodotto in via Tempini -. Nelle ore centrali la situazione diventa insostenibile. Gli ultimi giorni sono stati davvero caldi, per ritrovare una fine di giugno così rovente bisogna tornare indietro di anni».
In via Milano
Lungo via Milano ci sono diversi cantieri e di conseguenza diversi punti di vista sul tema. Tutti sostengono in ogni caso l’importanza assoluta di fermarsi durante le ore più calde. Ma se per il 50enne Luca Romele l’ordinanza è «un’iniziativa da lodare, che dimostra attenzione nei confronti del nostro duro lavoro», a Fabio Gerardini lascia qualche perplessità: «Non è una regola sbagliata – sostiene – ma fermarsi così presto può anche essere problematico, soprattutto per chi come noi opera sui sottoservizi. Non dico che non bisogna intervenire, ma chi fa questo lavoro sa che deve affrontare anche qualche situazione difficile, con il caldo e con il freddo».
L’operaio prosegue: «Bisogna invece pensare di tutelare le fragilità, e magari evitare che le persone oltre i 60 anni siano costrette a svolgere un’attività usurante come questa anziché andare in pensione». Dall’interno della cabina dell’escavatore che sta operando all’incrocio tra via Milano e via Camozzi, il capocantiere Luca Peli sostiene: «L’ordinanza è giustissima, ma doveva arrivare lunedì scorso. Anzi, direi già l’anno passato».
Tra i cantieri
Girando per i cantieri della città si ascolta frequentemente l’opinione che l’ordinanza regionale sia ineccepibile ma emanata con un po’ in ritardo. «Questa tipologia di ordinanza doveva essere prevista e non adottata in corsa – dichiara Francesco Ricco, direttore tecnico del cantiere edile di via Lucio Fiorentini a Sanpolino -. Visto che fa sempre più caldo, si pensi ad un protocollo nazionale che regoli la materia».
Dalle parole del direttore tecnico emerge come per la sua realtà le indicazioni dell’ordinanza siano la normalità. «In un contesto in cui si presta attenzione ai lavoratori, io investirei di più in prevenzione – afferma Ricco -. All’interno di cantieri molto grandi bisognerebbe avere fisso un defibrillatore. Perché purtroppo il malore può sempre capitare, anche se sei previdente».
Per gli operai la giornata si conclude con il consulto di Worklimate, il sito che con le sue previsioni di rischio regola l’entrata in vigore delle disposizioni: ma per loro una tregua dal caldo torrido pare ancora lontana. «L’ordinanza va bene, ma speriamo che la settimana prossima si abbassino le temperature – si augura Luca Peli -. se si scende a 27-28 gradi, si torna un attimo a respirare mentre si lavora».
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->construction and property
